text:
>  What makes a brief useful (or not useful) to you as a writer?
Specifics over generalities. A tone guide of "professional, friendly, smart" tells me nothing. That's what everyone wants. Or at least most people don't want the opposite.

Better is:

*Professional* means we don't bash others, or whine, or X. We refer to folks titles, especially if they're in the biz. We DO use slang when it comes to industry terms (e.g. _____), but we don't usually use general slang (e.g. "ain't").

etc.

elements.text: What makes a brief useful (or not useful) to you as a writer?

Specifics over generalities. A tone guide of "professional, friendly, smart" tells me nothing. That's what everyone wants. Or at least most people don't want the opposite.

Better is:
Professional

means we don't bash others, or whine, or X. We refer to folks titles, especially if they're in the biz. We DO use slang when it comes to industry terms (e.g. _____), but we don't usually use general slang (e.g. "ain't").

etc.

text:
Three big things I see teams leaving out that I think are important:

• *Giving the writer notes on how the brand views this particular topic.* For example, a WordPress theme company and a WordPress hosting company are going to have different approaches to writing about the same topic. Many companies will leave it to the writer to figure out, when a few sentences could point them in the right direction and prevent potential rewrites.
• *Clarifying who the audience is and why they care about this topic.* "Anyone searching for this keyword" isn't super helpful - do we want to appeal to all of them? Should we assume this audience is beginner or advanced in this topic area? What are the top 1-3 things they want to get out of this article?
• *Visual content guidelines.* I think it's rare that you can build an awesome piece of content without having some custom visual elements - not illustrations of featured images, but things like charts, diagrams, screenshots, etc. Ideally a brief should have some direction on potential graphics or elements to visualize, and also leave it open to the writer to suggest what these assets can be. That doesn't mean you should expect the writer to be building these graphics. My normal process would be having a graphic designer get started around the time the writer completes the first draft.

elements.text: Three big things I see teams leaving out that I think are important:
Giving the writer notes on how the brand views this particular topic.

For example, a WordPress theme company and a WordPress hosting company are going to have different approaches to writing about the same topic. Many companies will leave it to the writer to figure out, when a few sentences could point them in the right direction and prevent potential rewrites.
Clarifying who the audience is and why they care about this topic.

"Anyone searching for this keyword" isn't super helpful - do we want to appeal to all of them? Should we assume this audience is beginner or advanced in this topic area? What are the top 1-3 things they want to get out of this article?
Visual content guidelines.

I think it's rare that you can build an awesome piece of content without having some custom visual elements - not illustrations of featured images, but things like charts, diagrams, screenshots, etc. Ideally a brief should have some direction on potential graphics or elements to visualize, and also leave it open to the writer to suggest what these assets can be. That doesn't mean you should expect the writer to be building these graphics. My normal process would be having a graphic designer get started around the time the writer completes the first draft.

text: wooo! let's do this! welcome <@U026R1895QV> and thanks for doing this AMA with us! <@U026R1895QV> is the Director of Search Content at Search Engine Land and also runs the <http://SalaryNegotiationPro.com|SalaryNegotiationPro.com> newsletter. She's passionate about making sure that marketers are paid what they’re worth. After helping a few friends negotiate $10k, $15k, and $25k more in salary, she decided she could do greater good by starting <http://SalaryNegotiationPro.com|SalaryNegotiationPro.com> to help everyone become a pro at negotiation and make the money that makes their feel worth while. Feel free to drop questions for <@U026R1895QV> on raises, promotions, negotiating tips and more. I definitely recommend <https://salarynegotiationpro.com/|subscribing to her newsletter> and <https://twitter.com/CarolynLyden|following her on Twitter>.

text: Hi Carolyn, I just started working for a big fashion group as a freelance SEM specialist, hired through a remote agency.  I´m working well beyond the initial agreement but the agency owner says he needs the client to raise their advertising budgets in order to be able to pay me more. How would you handle it? In marketing it is hard to not answer to certain daily demands.

text:
A lot of the data I've seen seems to suggest that salaries tend to hit a ceiling between $100-200K for content marketing -- even at the Director/Head level. Do you agree with this?

If you do, why do you think this is and how can us content marketers combat this?

If you don't, I'd love to hear your thoughts on how high-level content marketers are breaking past that $200K mark.

elements.text:

If you do, why do you think this is and how can us content marketers combat this?

If you don't, I'd love to hear your thoughts on how high-level content marketers are breaking past that $200K mark.

text:
Hi Carolyn! I have a few questions that I'll space out. First one:

I've always negotiated salary but I have friends who hesitate in fear of blowback from HR and the hiring managers. Does that ever actually happen in practice? And what would you tell someone who is afraid of negotiation repercussions?

elements.text: Hi Carolyn! I have a few questions that I'll space out. First one:

I've always negotiated salary but I have friends who hesitate in fear of blowback from HR and the hiring managers. Does that ever actually happen in practice? And what would you tell someone who is afraid of negotiation repercussions?

text: Following up on that question, how do you document the agreed to alternative compensation? Is a mention in an offer letter enough? What will hold up when someone later says HR doesn’t approve or the whole department is under a new policy voiding previous agreements? Thanks!

text: My boss (at an agency) asked me for a 3-5 year financial plan when I last asked for a raise. He wants to know basically what i need to stay long term. He said to not just think about cash but also profit sharing/revenue sharing/equity and such. Bc we're an agency, I think equity is out as they won't sell, so it's worthless. But profit sharing or revenue sharing could work. Any thoughts on how to go through this sort of exercise? I'm honestly not sure where to start.

text:
Hey <@U026R1895QV> thanks for doing this! You’re doing some amazing things - I love the negotiation initiative and help for others!

I’m curious about SEL - regarding content strategy and topics. It’s fair to say the publication (longtime reader), is still quite SEO industry news-focused, yeah? Yet there’s a wealth of evergreen pieces of content!

I’m curious how you have defined that? Numerically? “For every 3 news articles let’s write 1 more evergreen article”? Or?

How have you gotten ahead of this and what tools, resources, and otherwise do you recommend to help facilitate, track, and manage your calendar/approach?

Great response (and great question) - I agree! At some point, it seems salary bands, ranges, location even, and the overall industry trends and realities just hit a cap. 

Radford data (and other) is heavily relied upon within most startups and other orgs, which could possibly be/become limiting whether intentionally or not.

text:
Full comp options:
• More paid vacation/a flexible work schedule
• Paid parking or transportation
• Continuing education/ conferences/tuition reimbursement
• Increased benefits or coverage
• Working from home setup/ telecommute tech options
• Signing bonus
• Paid moving expenses
• Guaranteed bonus at X months
• That corner office you’ve been eyeing (if you’re in-person)
• A new title
• A wardrobe allowance
• Guaranteed severance package
Only bring up full compensation AFTER you’ve negotiated for money.

elements.text: Full comp options:
More paid vacation/a flexible work schedule
Paid parking or transportation
Continuing education/ conferences/tuition reimbursement
Increased benefits or coverage
Working from home setup/ telecommute tech options
Signing bonus
Paid moving expenses
Guaranteed bonus at X months
That corner office you’ve been eyeing (if you’re in-person)
A new title
A wardrobe allowance
Guaranteed severance package
Only bring up full compensation AFTER you’ve negotiated for money.

text:
For what it’s worth, I’m very happy, grateful, and fortunate to have worked up to where I’m at. And I thrive in being both a specialist and generalist in content, growth, and beyond.

Still seeing the practice undervalued and underpaid in some companies still, though.

text:
Hi Lauren,
What makes content briefs useful to me as a freelancer writer:
1. Specifics in terms of possible sub-topics, it helps me narrow down exactly what direction the content is going and how best to write it during my own research. I find that whenever I get specifics, revisions are less as I often hit the client's expectation. 
2. Giving room for writer input. When a brief is too strict, it often means excluding other information that could have made the content better. And the client isn't happy because their content is just like everything that is out there. This could easily be prevented if there was more room for me to add to the brief as the writer. 
3. Adding tone of voice for the brand. Knowing exactly how a brand writes their content makes it easy for me to produce content that sounds the same as their other pieces.
4. Giving a clear direction in terms of "here is the angle we want to take on this piece". The direction a software maker brand will take on a topic will differ from that of a software user brand will.

elements.text:
Hi Lauren,
What makes content briefs useful to me as a freelancer writer:

Specifics in terms of possible sub-topics, it helps me narrow down exactly what direction the content is going and how best to write it during my own research. I find that whenever I get specifics, revisions are less as I often hit the client's expectation.

Giving room for writer input. When a brief is too strict, it often means excluding other information that could have made the content better. And the client isn't happy because their content is just like everything that is out there. This could easily be prevented if there was more room for me to add to the brief as the writer.
Adding tone of voice for the brand. Knowing exactly how a brand writes their content makes it easy for me to produce content that sounds the same as their other pieces.
Giving a clear direction in terms of "here is the angle we want to take on this piece". The direction a software maker brand will take on a topic will differ from that of a software user brand will.

elements.text: Thank you,

text: :pray::pray::pray:
Be succinct, don’t talk down to the writer, be clear about how the voice should sound, and _for the love of Pete_, clarify which notes are the most important and where priorities lie.
